name: Broccoli
description: Broccoli grows best in cool weather—use an indoor start and a clear transplant window to stay ahead of heat in short seasons.
frostTolerance: Moderate to high (light frosts are usually fine)
tagline: Broccoli likes cool weather — plan for steady growth, not heat.
lede:
Broccoli performs well in cool climates, but it needs consistent moisture and timing.
        In short seasons, an indoor start and a clear transplant window improve reliability.
indexBlurb: Cool-season timing, transplant windows, and avoiding heat stress.

name: Kale
description: Kale is one of the most forgiving short-season crops—start early and keep it growing into fall.
tagline: Reliable, cold-tolerant, and one of the best short-season crops.
lede:
Kale handles cool weather better than most vegetables and keeps producing into fall.
        It’s a great “backbone crop” for short seasons.
indexBlurb: Reliable cool-season crop with flexible sowing and strong fall performance.

name: Spinach
description: Spinach prefers cool temperatures—timing matters more than fertilizing in short seasons.
tagline: Cold-hardy, fast, and perfect for early spring and fall.
lede:
Spinach thrives in cool weather. In short seasons, it’s an ideal crop because it can be sown early,
        harvested quickly, and planted again for fall.
indexBlurb: Direct sow timing for cool soil, bolt avoidance, and fall sowing options.

name: Tomatoes
description: Tomatoes can succeed in short seasons with the right indoor start window and early varieties.
tagline: Timing, variety choice, and protection matter more than anything else.
lede:
Tomatoes are one of the most rewarding crops in a home garden — but in shorter climates,
        they require intentional planning. With the right start date and variety selection,
        reliable harvests are absolutely possible.
indexBlurb: Indoor start timing, variety selection, and fall maturity planning.

name: Peppers
description: Peppers need a longer runway than tomatoes—start indoors early and protect heat.
tagline: Peppers reward patience — but they need an early start.
lede:
Peppers are slower than tomatoes in cool climates. In a short growing season,
        a strong indoor start and warm transplant conditions make the difference.
indexBlurb: Longer indoor start window, warmth needs, and transplant timing.
